questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC class I activates which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Cytotoxic T cells 

Antigen binding to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I activates cytotoxic T cells. The major histocompatibility complex (MHC), is a genetic locus that encodes a group of antigens. The MHC molecules also bind peptide antigens and present them to the T cells. The human MHC is called the human leukocyte antigen (HLA) complex.

questions.text: Which of the following agents can be used as a disinfectant but not a sanitizer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Hydrogen peroxide

Hydrogen peroxide is a disinfectant but cannot be used as a sanitizer.

questions.text: What is the microscopy technique to produce high contrast image of transparent, live bacteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Phase contrast microscopy 

The microscopy technique used to produce high contrast images of transparent, live bacteria is phase contrast microscopy.

choices.text: Direct spread from mesenteric lymph nodes

questions.text: Mode of transmission of abdominal TB includes all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Feco-oral route 

Abdominal tuberculosis (TB) is not transmitted by feco-oral route.

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to have endemic transmission in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever caused by nairovirus has an endemic transmission in India.

questions.text: Which virus can be identified by a PCR method and is endemic to India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

West nile virus 

West Nile virus can be identified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and is endemic to India. West Nile virus is a flavivirus that is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes. It can be subclinical or may present as a mild influenza-like illness. Encephalitis occurs in severe forms. Reverse transcriptase PCR has been used to identify the virus

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Roseola infantum 

Roseola infantum is not associated with petechial rashes. Roseola infantum, also known as exanthem subitum or sixth disease, is caused by human herpes viruses 6 and 7 and is an acute febrile illness that presents with a rose-pink maculopapular eruption after the fever subsides. It initially develops on the neck and trunk and may spread to the arms, face, and leg. They are surrounded by pallor and rarely become vesicular.

choices.text: Real-time PCR to detect viral MRNA
Rapid antigen test to detect spike proteins

questions.text: SARS-CoV-2 can be detected by all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Southern blotting 

SARS-CoV-2 can be detected by all except Southern blotting. Southern blotting cannot be used to detect SARSCoV-2 because there is usually not enough DNA in the collected sample to obtain a pattern on gel electrophoresis.  Real-time PCR uses nasopharyngeal secretions to detect viral genomic RNA or DNA in respiratory secretions. It is the most sensitive and specific test available.

questions.text: What is the ratio of T cells to B cells ina healthy adult?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

3:1 

The ratio of T cells to B cells in the blood of a healthy adult is approximately 3:1. T lymphocytes constitute 60-70% of lymphocytes in the blood while mature B cells account for 10-20%

questions.text:
Which of the following are acid-fast staining organisms?

1. Nocardia

2. Mycobacterium leprae

3. Actinomyces

4. Cryptosporidium parvum

5. Isospora belli
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

1,2,4,5 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Cytoisospora belli are acid-fast staining organisms.

questions.text: The inclusion body rickettsial morula is found in neutrophils during infection caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum 

The inclusion body rickettsial morula is found in granulocytes (neutrophils) during infection caused by Anaplasma phagocytophilum.

questions.text: Vesicular rash is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Hand, foot, and mouth disease 

Vesicular rash is seen in hand, foot, and mouth disease. It is a mild exanthematous fever usually occurring in children but may also occur in adults. It is characterized by papulovesicular rashes that involve the oral mucosa, palms, and soles. The virus is shed in the stool and is transmitted by the feco-oral route. It is a self-limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks. Treatment is symptomatic as the rash heals spontaneously

choices.text: Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes
IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anti-CMV IgG antibodies?
questions.solution:
Correrct Answer (D) 

IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

Anti-CMV IgG indicates past exposure / immunity, not active infection. IgG avidity testing helps distinguish recent (primary) CMV infection from past infections by measuring how strongly IgG binds CMV antigens; low avidity suggests recent infection, high avidity suggests past exposure.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As a part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was done. What is the principle of this test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Heterophile antibodies

The principle of the Paul-Bunnell test is based on heterophile antibodies. Heterophile antibodies have the ability to agglutinate shared antigens.

questions.text: All of the following oncogenic viruses can integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

HTLV 

HTLV - Human T cell lymphotropic virus causes microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms. Even, Hepatitis C virus, a flavivirus, does not generate a provirus and appears to induce cancer indirectly.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient had a tooth extraction three days back. He now presents with a mass in the submandibular region which is otherwise asymptomatic. There is no ulcer on the oral mucosa. On drainage of the discharge, it was foul-smelling with a lot of yellow granules. They showed gram-positive filamentous rods on grams staining. What is the most likely implicated pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Actinomycetes israelli 

This is a case of Cervicofacial actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces israeli. It presents as a painless nodule that indurates with purulent discharge that contains sulfur granules giving it a yellow color. Sulfur granules are composed of a matrix of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following causes aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Parvovirus 

Aplastic crisis in a child with hereditary spherocytosis is most likely due to infection of parvovirus. This aplastic crisis is due to the transient arrest of erythropoiesis where the parvovirus infects and kills the red cell precursors. This generally leads to a sudden worsening of anemia. Transfusions may be necessary to support the patient until the immune response clears the infection.

questions.text: Which cell is involved in type 4/delayed type hypersensitivity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Cytotoxic T cell 

Cytotoxic T cells are involved in type 4/delayed type hypersensitivity

questions.text: Which of the following is a dematiaceous fungus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Cladosporium 

Cladosporium is the dematiaceous fungus in the given options. Dematiaceous fungi are fungi whose cell walls contain melanin, which imparts a brown to black color. Phialophora verrucosa, Fonsecaea pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, Rhinocladiella aquaspersa, and Cladophialophora (Cladosporium) carrionii are examples of dematiaceous fungi

choices.text: Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles
Fasciola hepatica acquired through contaminated water
Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections

questions.text: Which of the following statements is True regarding trematodes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles 

Among trematodes, the only true statement is that Fasciola hepatica resides in the intrahepatic biliary radicles. Schistosomes are dioecious, Fasciola hepatica is acquired by ingesting metacercariae encysted on raw aquatic vegetation, and triclabendazole is not the universal treatment for all trematode infections, since praziquantel is used to manage schistosomiasis and lung fluke infections.
